p.s: I think Gatsby does right by reviving this relationship.
We know how Tom treated his mistress so it's possible that he treats Daisy hardly any better.
Going from this stance it would be great for Daisy to leave the relationship with Tom especially if she loves Gatsby.
And in the book the chances are not too bad.
She may loved Tom at one point in her life but in the book it seems like she likes Gatsby better.
The only thing coming between her and Gatsby is her hitting Myrtle Wilson with her car and Mr. Wilson revenging his wife by killing Gatsby because he thought Gatsby drove the car.
Hadn't they driven TomsTom's car and caused Myrtle storming onto the street, the whole thing could have ended lucky for them.
In general I would say that it depends on your and the other personsperson's situation.
If one said that the person is married happy, it would be highly unethical to pull them out of their life by rententering it, and maybe ruining their marriage.
But if the situation of the other person in the right state, there shouldn't be a problem reviving a past relationship.
Especially if you consider that this can lead to new relationships.
